article_text:
Public hospital CEO ousted

Photo: Cody Duty, Staff David Lopez, president and CEO of the Harris County Hospital...

David Lopez, the executive in charge of running Harris County's $1.1 billion health care system for the poor, was ousted from his post Monday at a special meeting of the Harris Health System board of managers.

article_metadata.description: David Lopez, the executive in charge of running Harris County's $1.1 billion health care system for the poor, was ousted from his post Monday at a special meeting of the Harris Health System board of managers.  The facilities in 2013 served 350,000 patients through more than 1.75 million clinic appointments and hospitals stays, only a tiny fraction of which were paid through private insurance.  Harris County Commissioner Steve Radack, a frequent critic of Lopez, faulted the lack of a coherent vision at the system, which faces an uncertain future under health care reform, particularly given Texas' decision to forgo billions of dollars in federal funding and not participate in Medicaid expansion.  At one system board of managers meeting, Lopez drew a sharp rebuke from the presidents of Baylor College of Medicine and the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston about the state of relations with the schools' doctors that staff the Ben Taub and LBJ hospitals.  In September, Harris Health had to pay more than $4 million in back wages and damages to nearly 4,600 current and former employees after an investigation by the U.S. Department of Labor's Wage and Hour Division found it violated the overtime and record-keeping provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act.
article_metadata.author.name: By Todd Ackerman
